Dear Melynda Elizabeth Williams:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/20/24, youth was in the facility parking lot and struggling.
Youth was able to access staff vehicle that was left unlocked.
There was a gun in the door. Youth did not access the gun. The
staff member will be terminated.
Investigation Interviews:
All of the following interviews were completed on 06/25/2024 at
Whaley’s Children’s Center in Flint, MI unless otherwise noted.
Compliance Supervisor was interviewed and advised of the
allegations of the special investigation. She confirmed that the
incident had occurred. She provided copies of the incident reports
and agency policy that is assessed to have been violated. She
further confirmed that Staff 1 had been terminated effective
6/21/2024.
Youth A was interviewed and confirmed that he was upset, so he
went into the parking lot of the agency and began to check for
unlocked cars. He reported that he got into one of the unlocked
cars and began honking the horn. He then noticed a gun was in
the drivers side door. He stated that he did not touch the gun and
told Supervisor 1 it was a gun in the car. She told him to get out of
the car and he reported that he did. He reported that the car
belonged to Staff 1. He knew this because he has seen him drive
it to work. He denied seeing any other weapons on the campus
and reported he feels safe at the agency.
Staff 2 was interviewed and confirmed that she was working on
6/20/2024. She recalled that she walked out of the unit and saw
Supervisor 1 outside of the administration building. Supervisor 1
motioned for Staff 2 to come over and assist her in the parking lot.
Staff 2 reported that Supervisor 1 quietly and quickly gave her an
update about what was going on and advised that there was a gun
in the car that Youth A had just exited. Staff 2 stated she then
locked the doors to the car and called for additional assistance.
Staff 2 reported that the car belonged to Staff 1.
2

Supervisor 1 was interviewed and confirmed she was present the
day of the incident. She recalled that Youth A was upset because
he was unable to go on an outing and began acting out. He
ended up in the parking lot and entered the car of Staff 1 and it
was found to have a gun in the car. Supervisor 1 reported she
was able to keep Youth A calm and convince him to exit the car.
She reported Youth A did not touch the gun and once he saw it,
he informed staff. Supervisor 1 had Staff 2 monitor Youth A while
she dealt with Staff 1 and his violation of policy relevant to having
a weapon on the premises.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed. Both youth confirmed
having heard about Youth A finding a gun in a vehicle in the
parking lot but did not see a gun or see any youth with a gun.
Both youth denied seeing weapons on the campus and neither
had ever attempted to check for unlocked vehicles in the parking
lot.
On 07/03/2024 an in-person interview was held with Complainant
and no additional concerns were noted.
On 07/24/2024 an attempted telephone call was made to Staff 1.
A message was left requesting a return telephone call. On
8/13/2024 an additional telephone call was made and it was noted
that the phone number was no longer in service.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Report #1 – dated 06/20/2024 and authored by
Supervisor 1. It indicated that Youth A was upset and stated he
was going to go AWOL. Staff attempted to redirect. He left the
unit after destroying property and staff followed. Youth A was able
to gain access to the main building and ran around in the building
before coming back out and heading toward the parking lot. Staff
continued attempts to redirect his behavior. Once in the parking
lot Youth A began to check doors for any openings. Youth A was
successful in finding a car door that was unlocked and got in.
Once in, Youth A noticed a gun and told the staff that there was a
gun inside of the car. Staff encouraged him to remain calm and
exit the vehicle, which he eventually did.
Incident Report #2 – dated 06/20/2024 and authored by Staff 2.
The report indicated that Staff 2 was heading back to Main
campus and was flagged down for assistance by Supervisor 1. At
this time, Youth A was exiting the vehicle. Supervisor 1 provided
a quick update. Youth A began attempts to enter other unlocked
3

cars. He blew the horns and got in and out of the cars. Youth A
eventually stated, “I’m Done Now”. He returned to the unit but
continued his escalation because he said he was upset that he did
not get to go on the field trip with other youth.
Whaley’s Children Center Vehicle Policy – Indicates that all
vehicles must be kept locked, and windows rolled up when not in
use.
Whaley’s Children Center Workplace Violence Prevention Policy –
prohibits the possession of weapons on its property at all times,
including parking lots and company vehicles.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage was reviewed and it showed the parking lot located
outside of Whaley Main building. Youth A could be seen running
in the parking lot and checking doors to see if they were unlocked.
Youth A can be seen getting into a vehicle and staff are standing
around attempting to encourage him to exit the car. There is no
audio to the video, but the participants appear to be engaging in
conversation. Youth A is seen getting out of the car and then
checking the locks on other car doors before going back into one
of the buildings.
Analysis The agency is found to be in non-compliance of licensing rule
4109-C. After the completion of interviews of staff and youth it
was confirmed that Staff 1 had a weapon on agency premises
which is a violation of the agency policy.
Technical Assistance
As it relates to the requirement that all vehicles, both company
and personal, remained locked on the premises the agency policy
was not clear that this applied to both company vehicles and staff
vehicles. The policy that references locked doors of the vehicles
can only be found in the policy titled WCC Vehicle Policy. It is
recommended that the agency make adjustment to the policy to
make it clear that the requirement for vehicle doors to remain
locked applies to all vehicles on the premises, including the
vehicles of staff.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
